*   Moving to (8, 3) (UP) brings me closer to (7, 5). Distance to (7, 5) becomes $\sqrt{(8-7)^2 + (3-5)^2} = \sqrt{1+4} = \sqrt{5} \approx 2.2$. (If I go UP, next turn I could try RIGHT or UP again).
*   Moving to (9, 2) (RIGHT) is poor for immediate targets.
*   Moving to (8, 1) (DOWN) is poor for immediate targets.

Moving UP to (8, 3) seems strategically advantageous as it targets the visually closer high-Y apple (7, 5) sooner, potentially allowing me to move towards the cluster of apples in the top-right quadrant later (6, 8), (6, 9), (9, 9).

If I go UP to (8, 3), the next step could be LEFT to (7, 3) or UP to (8, 4). This seems like a reasonable approach towards (7, 5).

*   Move UP to (8, 4): Distance to (7, 5) becomes $\sqrt{(8-7)^2 + (4-5)^2} = \sqrt{1+1} = \sqrt{2} \approx 1.41$. This seems to move me closer in terms of Euclidean distance! (Wait, $\sqrt{5} \approx 2.23$. $\sqrt{2}$ is smaller).

If I choose LEFT to (7, 3), next turn I can try UP to (7, 4) or UP to (7, 5) (if that is beneficial).

T3: (7, 3) -> UP -> (7, 4). Distance to (7, 5) is 1.
T4: (7, 4) -> UP -> (7, 5) **(Eat Apple!)**

Enemy Snake #0 is far away at (2, 8). No immediate threat.

I prefer the path that keeps me higher up, so UP seems marginally better for overall board positioning related to the upper apples.

Long-term plan: Continue moving towards apple (7, 5) using the sequence UP, LEFT, UP. Be aware of the possibility of finding shorter paths or encountering opponents.
